metadata.title: Suspension of surface-modified nano-SiO2 in partially hydrolyzed aqueous solution of polyacrylamide for enhanced oil recovery

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Colloids and Surfaces A
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/colsurfa
Suspension of surface-modified nano-SiO2 in partially hydrolyzed aqueous solution of polyacrylamide for enhanced oil recovery
Chao Zhenga, Yamin Chenga, Qingbo Weia, Xiaohong Lia,b, Zhijun Zhanga,b,⁎
a Engineering Research Center for Nanomaterials, Henan University, Kaifeng, 475001, China b National & Local Joint Engineering Research Center for Applied Technology of Hybrid Nanomaterials, Henan University, Kaifeng 475001, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Surface-modified nano-SiO2 HPAM High-temperature High-salinity Enhanced oil recovery
A B S T R A C T
In high-temperature and high-salinity oil reservoirs, the poor thermal stability and salinity tolerance of partially hydrolyzed polyacrylamides (HPAM) solution hinder its efficiency in enhanced oil recovery (EOR). Therefore, a series of dispersible nano-SiO2 (denoted as DNS) separately surface-modified by silane coupling agents hexamethyldisilazane (denoted as HMDS) and hexadecyltrimethoxysilane (denoted as HDTS) are prepared by in-situ surface-modification technique. The two types of surface-modified hydrophobic nano-SiO2, i.e., DNS-HM (modified by HMDS) and DNS-HD (modified by HDTS), are separately added into HPAM solution to obtain the HPAM-based suspensions used for EOR. The effects of DNS-HM and DNS-HD on the thermal stability, apparent viscosity, and flooding performance of HPAM are investigated. The results indicate that the HPAM/DNS-HM8 and HPAM/DNS-HD16 (see Table 1) suspensions exhibit better apparent viscosity, storage stability and thermal stability than the HPAM/DNS-0 suspensions. Moreover, HPAM/DNS-HM8 suspension show better flooding performance and has a higher oil recovery factor (about 10.54%) than other HPAM-based suspensions.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Enhanced oil recovery (EOR) is a technique to increase oil recovery by improving microscopic and macroscopic sweep efficiency [1]. As an important method to EOR, polymer flooding is applied to many oil fields [2,3]. Besides, as the most widely used polyacrylamide in polymer flooding, partially hydrolyzed polyacrylamides (HPAM) is drawing more and more attention [4,5]. However, with new oilfield exploitation and more and more reservoirs, featuring high-temperature environment and hard brines characteristics, are found around the world. Issues of HPAM, such as poor salt tolerance and weak thermal stability, have become increasingly prominent [6,7]. These disadvantages of HPAM solution limit its applications in the hostile environment oil reservoirs.
Numerous efforts have been made to improve the thermal stability and salinity tolerance of HPAM [8], and it has been primarily found that the suspensions of inorganic nanoparticles with polymer contributes to improving the thermal stability and salinity tolerance of HPAM as a medium of polymer flooding [9–12]. Particularly, due to the interaction between polymer and nano-SiO2, HPAM/nano-SiO2 suspensions exhibits better viscosity-temperature characteristics than HPAM solution under high-temperature and high-salinity conditions [13–15]. D. Zhu et al. studied the effect of unmodified silica nanoparticles on the rheological of hydrophobically associating polyacrylamides (HAPAM),
it was found that the apparent viscosity and elastic modulus of HAPAM solution increased with addition of silica nanoparticles [9]. A Maghzi et al. explored the impact of silica nanoparticles on the performance of polymer solution in presence of salts, the results showed that silica nanosuspension in polyacrylamide have helped increase the viscosity of polyacrylamide and its viscosity increase with the concentration of silica nanoparticles [16]. A. Rezaei et al. used surface modified clay nanoparticles to improve rheological behavior of HPAM solution, the experimental result indicates that adding optimum concentration of surface modified clay nanoparticles improves rheological behavior and stability of polymer solution [17]. C.P. Whitby et al. reported similar action of nano-SiO2 in increasing the structure stability and viscosity of polyacrylic acid suspensions and polyethylene suspensions [18]. The reason lies in that nano-SiO2 is able to prevent polyacrylamide from degradation in brine, thereby resulting in increased oil recovery during flooding at a high concentration of nano-silica. Maurya et al. and Zhang et al. also independently claimed that nano-silica can not only increase the injected fluid viscosity but also lead to better salt tolerance for polymer solution, thereby showing potential for EOR [8,19]. However, nano-silica often exhibits poor compatibility with polymers, which does not favor its application in polymer-based flooding medium. On the other hand, as the increasingly rigorous situation of many new-found oil fields exploiting environment, there is no doubt that further research and development of HPAM with improved thermal stability and salinity

tolerance is imminent. There are some papers reported the application of hydrophobic nanoparticles of SiO2 in EOR. Q. Di et al’s experimental showed that the hydrophobic nanoparticles of SiO2 could be adsorbed tightly on the surface of the porous wall to form a strong hydrophobic layer, which contributed to increase the water-phase effective permeabilities [20]. M.A. Ahmadi et al. studied the ability of hydrophobic nanoparticles of SiO2 in EOR process though carbonate rock samples. Their observations indicated hydrophobic nanosilica can lower interfacial tension between oil and water and then reduce the mobility ratio between oil and nanofluid [21]. However, as far as we know, nano-SiO2 surface modified by hydrophilic groups suspensions in HPAM solution, which is few reports in previous papers. Due to the formation of hydrogen bonds between the amide groups of HPAM and the hydroxyl groups of modified nano-SiO2, the hydrophobic groups can be randomly distributed along the silica nanoparticles in polymer solution [10,22]. Because of the modified nano-SiO2 suspensions in aqueous solution, hydrophobic groups tend to aggregate and form a micro-region by hydrophobic association action. Due to the hydrogen bonds, associating interactions and Van der Waals between silica nanoparticles and HPAM, a steadier three-dimensional association network structure is easily constructed in aqueous solution. Based on that analysis, it is concluded that nano-SiO2 surface-modified by hydrophobic groups would act as physical crosslinkers between polymer molecules. These small amount of hydrophobic groups which on the surface of nano-SiO2 will play an important role in improving thermal stability and salt tolerance of HPAM, so there is a wide application prospect in oil exploration.
In this article, a series of hydrophobic nano-SiO2 (DNS) surface modified by different hydrophobic groups and various modified amount were prepared. The effect of DNS-0 and modified nano-SiO2 (DNS-HM, DNS-HD) on the HPAM viscosity behaviors in the high-temperature and high-salinity is investigated. Additionally, in order to examine the effect of nano-SiO2 on the HPAM performance in EOR, a number of core flooding tests were carried out. Then, the efficacy of pure HPAM solution, HPAM/DNS-0, HPAM/DNS-HM and HPAM/DNS-HD suspensions to EOR are compared in harsh conditions. For simplicity, the above nano-SiO2 modified by different modifier and various modified amount have been named as Table 1 shows.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
Dispersible nano-SiO2 (DNS) was prepared with the method established at our laboratory [23]. Silane coupling agents HMDS and HDTS were purchased from Nanjing Pinning Coupling Agent Company (Nanjing, China). The two series of nano-SiO2 (DNS-HM and DNS-HD) were prepared at our laboratory. HPAM with an average molecular weight of 2 × 107 g/mol was purchased from Henan Wujiangshui Materials Company (Gongyi, China). The quartz sand with a size of 200–300 mesh was purchased from Zhenxing Quartz Sand Factory (Luoyang, China). The crude oil was provided by Shengli oilfield in China, with a viscosity of 479.8 mPa s at 25 °C. The water used in this
experiment was distilled followed by deionization.
2.2. Preparation of surface-modified nano-SiO2
DNS-0, DNS-HM and DNS-HD were prepared by in-situ surface modification method. Fig. 1 schematically shows the processes for fabricating DNS-0, DNS-HM and DNS-HD. Briefly, sodium metasilicate is hydrolyzed to generate Si(OH)4 monomer. Resultant Si(OH)4 monomer undergoes condensation polymerization to afford silica spheres containing active hydroxyl group on the surface, that is the DNS-0 (Fig. 1(a)). Then silane coupling agent HMDS or HDTS was added into the three-neck flask charged with resultant DNS-0 solution and using ammonia to adjust the pH value close to 9, the flask was then placed in water bath at 50 °C with a stirring rate of 400 ± 20 rpm for 1 h and then heating up to 80 °C for another 1 h. At the end of the surfacemodification reaction, the product was washed with distilled water to obtain the target product DNS-HM and DNS-HD, as shown in Fig. 1(b) and (c).

sections.heading: 2.3. Preparation of HPAM/DNS suspensions and simulated Shengli brine
sections.text:
HPAM/DNS suspensions were prepared in two steps: firstly, the filtered cake of DNS was fully dispersed in distilled water with the assistance of 30 min of ultrasonic vibration; secondly, the mother liquor of HPAM (5000 mg/L) was added into the aqueous dispersion of DNS and gently stirred for 48 h. The obtained HPAM/DNS suspensions should meet the requirements of no visible macroscopic phase separation after storage for 12 h at room temperature.
Simulated Shengli brine (total dissolved solids: 5727 mg/L; [Ca2+ + Mg2+]: 108 mg/L) was composed of 0.1330 g of sodium sulfate, 4.6880 g of sodium chloride, 0.2220 g of anhydrous calcium chloride, 0.2370 g of magnesium chloride hexahydrate, 0.5510 g of sodium bicarbonate, and 994.17 g of deionized water. These solid chemicals were sequentially dissolved into the distilled water under mechanical stir to obtained stable and transparent solution.

sections.heading: 2.4.1. Contact angle measurement
sections.text: The contact angle measurement was performed using a drop shape analyzer 25 (KRÜSS, Germany). The films were prepared by dipping the mud of modified nano-SiO2 evenly on the surface of the slide, and then dried under suitable temperature. About 6 μL of distilled water was carefully dropped through the 0.5 mm outer diameter needle tip on the top surface of the modified nano-SiO2, and the photographs of the contact angle was measured after 3 seconds. The two series of modified nano-SiO2 DNS-HM, DNS-HD and unmodified nano-SiO2 DNS-0 were measured at room temperature.

sections.heading: 2.4.2. Structure characterization
sections.text: The Fourier transform infrared spectra (FT-IR) of DNS-HM and DNSHD were registered in solid sate using a KBr pellet method in the transmittance mode. A Nicolet FT-IR (AVATAR360, Nigaoli Instrument Company, USA) was used to record the spectra within the scanning range of 400–4000 cm−1. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of DNSHM and DNS-HD in nitrogen atmosphere was conducted with an EXSTAR 6000 thermal analysis system (Seiko Instrument Inc, Japan) in the temperature range of 25–800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min.

sections.heading: 2.4.3. Evaluation of viscosity-temperature characteristics
sections.text:
The effects of DNS-0, DNS-HM, and DNS-HD on the viscosity of HPAM under high-temperature and high-salinity conditions were investigated with a NDJ-8S digital viscometer (Shanghai Ande Instrument Equipment Company; Shanghai, China). The viscosity of various HPAM/DNS suspensions in distilled water and simulated oilfield brine was measured in the temperature range of 30–80 °C. A
thermostatic water bath produced by Zhengzhou Great Wall Technology Company (Zhengzhou, China) was performed to control the temperature.

sections.heading: 2.4.4. Core flooding test
sections.text:
Simulation cores were made by sandpack which is 2.5 cm in diameter and 20 cm in length. The simulation core is prepared as follows: Firstly, the quartz sands were washed and aged at 200 °C for 24 h; secondly, crude oil and the quartz sands evenly mixed in the fixed proportion and then placed in an oven and aged at 80 °C for 12 h to obtain the oil quartz sands. In this paper, oil content of the oil quartz sands is 0.2643 mL/g. Lastly, the oil quartz sands were added into sandpack follow the pattern of “little amount many times”, and using isostatic press to compact the oil quartz sands in every time. Four sandstone cores were prepared, and their basic parameters are listed in
Table 2. A series of core flooding tests were conducted to examine the effect of nano-SiO2 on the flooding performance of HPAM in EOR at 80 °C temperature. The simulation cores flooding experimental steps are as follows[24]: Frist, the core is saturated with distilled water, following which the porosity and pore volume (PV) are calculated. Second, the 2.5 PV of distilled water is injected at the flow rate of 0.5 mL/min, our experiment results suggest that the water content is more than 98% in produced fluid when the injected PV of water reached 2.5 PV. Third, the 0.6 PV polymer slug is injected and then 1 PV of subsequent water flooding were carried out, both of them are injected at the flow rate of 0.5 mL/min. The whole experimentation is carried out at 80 °C temperature.

sections.heading: 3.1. Contact angle measurement
sections.text: The contact angle of two series of modified nano-SiO2 (DNS-HM, DNS-HD16) and unmodified nano-SiO2 (DNS-0) were detected by a drop shape analyzer and the results are presented in Fig. 2(a)–(d) are the photographs of the contact angle measurement of DNS-HM, it can be observed that the contact angle of DNS-HM range from 0 to 144.5° as increasing the molar ratio of DNS-0 to HMDS from 1/32 to 1/4. Fig. 2(c), (f), (j) are the photographs of the contact angle measurement of DNS-HD, it also can be seen that the contact angle of DNS-HD range from 0° to 141.8° as increasing the molar ratio of DNS-0 to HDTS from 1/32 to 1/8. Fig. 2(k) is the contact angle measurement of DNS-0, its contact angle is 0°, which represents the unmodified nano-SiO2 is hydrophilic. According to the results of contact angle, it can be concluded that the hydrophobic groups, come from HMDS and HDTS, have been successfully grafted onto the surface of nano-SiO2.

sections.heading: 3.2. FT-IR spectroscopy and TGA
sections.text:
Fig. 3(a) shows the FT-IR spectra of DNS-HM8 and DNS-HD16. The absorption bands in the wavenumber range from 400 cm−1 to 4000 cm−1 and peaks located at 471, 801, and 1107 cm−1 correspond to the bending vibration, symmetric stretching vibration and asym-
metric stretching vibration of SieOeSi, respectively. The absorption band at 1631 cm−1 corresponds to the bending vibration of HeOeH, and the one at 3426 cm−1 corresponds to the stretching vibration of OeH [25,26]. Besides, the absorption peak at 2966 cm−1 corresponds to the bending vibration of eCH3, and DNS-HM8 shows the bending vibration peak of eCH2 at 2860 cm−1. Based on the FT-IR it is easy to deduce the bending vibration eCH3 and eCH2 come from modification reagents—HMDS and HDTS.
As shown in Fig. 3(b), the indication of DNS-0, DNS-HM8 and DNSHD16 were measured by TGA. The curve of DNS-0 shows obvious loss (about 5%) in first temperature zone (25–130 °C) because of the removal of the absorbed water and hydroxyl groups. But, in contrast, both DNS-HM8 and DNS-HD16 have smaller weight loss (about 2.5%) in the first temperature zone, which is due to the chemical bonding of the surface hydroxyl groups displaced by hydrophobic groups. However, there is obvious bigger weight loss in the curve of DNS-HM8 and DNS-HD16 than DNS-0, attributing to the decomposition and breakage of organic carbon chain on the surface of DNS-HM8 and DNS-HD16 [27]. The results of FT-IR and TGA indicate that hydrophobic groups are modified on the surface of nano-SiO2 successfully.
Fig. 4 shows the FT-IR spectra of HPAM and HPAM/DNS-HM. Both HPAM and HPAM/DNS-HM8 exhibit identical absorption bands in the wavenumber ranging from 600 cm−1 to 4000 cm−1, including the characteristic absorptions of the amino group (3340.5 cm−1) and the carbonyl group (1162.0 cm−1) of HPAM. Moreover, the amide absorp-
tion peaks of HPAM/DNS-HM8 are shifted to lower wavenumbers (3333.1 cm−1 and 1597.2 cm−1), indicating a substantial red shift. In the meantime, HPAM/DNS-HM8 shows a new peak at 1080.1 cm−1, and this new peak is attributed to the asymmetric stretching vibration of SieOeSi. These FT-IR data demonstrate that hydrogen bonds are formed between the amide group of HPAM and the silanol on the surface of DNS-HM in HPAM/DNS-HM8 suspensions [28].

sections.heading: 3.3. Viscosity of HPAM/DNS suspensions
sections.text:
The viscosity of various HPAM/DNS suspensions is shown in Fig. 5. It can be seen that the viscosity of HPAM/DNS-0 suspensions in water increases with the increase in the concentration of DNS-0 (Fig. 5(a)). Similarly, the viscosity of HPAM/DNS-0 suspensions in the simulated Shengli brine also tends to rise with increasing concentration of DNS-0 (Fig. 5(b)). The viscosity of HPAM/DNS-0 suspensions in distilled water and in simulated Shengli brine tends to slightly decrease with elevating temperature, which is consistent with some previous papers [29]. However, the viscosity of HPAM/DNS-0 suspensions was much different in simulated Shengli brine and in distilled water. Similar to DNS-0, DNS-HM and DNS-HD can helps improve the viscosity of HPAM solution in water and in the Shengli brine, and the viscosity of HPAM/DNS-HM and HPAM/DNS-HD suspensions tends to increase significantly with the increase the concentration DNS-HM or DNS-HD concentration (Fig. 5(c) and (d)). HPAM/DNS-HD16 exhibits a relatively high viscosity among HPAM/DNS-HD suspensions in distilled water, while HPAM/DNS-HM8 exhibits a relatively high viscosity among HPAM/DNS-HM suspensions in distilled water. The reason for HPAM/DNS-HD16 and HPAM/DNS-HM8 exhibit higher viscosity than others is because DNS-HM8 and DNS-HD16 are the relative optimum modified amount in the series of DNS-HM and DNS-HD, respectively. The viscosity of HPAM/DNS has a closely related with the hydrophobicity of nano-SiO2. High hydrophobicity is not beneficial to the suspension of nano-SiO2 in aqueous solutions, on the other hand low hydrophobicity lead to nano-SiO2 cannot do more in hydrophobic association. So, high hydrophobicity or low hydrophobicity were not beneficial to nano-SiO2 play a bigger role in enhances the hydrophobic association action so that cannot make HPAM/DNS solution exhibit higher viscosity. Further experiments reveal that HPAM/DNS-HM8 suspensions have a better salinity tolerance than HPAM/HD16 suspensions (Fig. 5(e)), it indicated that the kinds of hydrophobic groups modified on the surface of nano-SiO2 have an impact on the viscosity of HPAM/DNS solution, there are different hydrophobic groups on the surface of DNS-HM and DNS-HD. Appropriate hydrophobic group is able to make HPAM/DNS solution achieve the higher viscosity, so we
think DNS-HM8 is superior to DNS-HD16 in improving the viscosity of HPAM solution. Besides, the major difference between DNS-HM and DNS-HD is the hydrophobic groups which with different length of carbon chain, we hypothesized that the length of carbon chain maybe has a big effect on the viscosity of HPAM/DNS solution, there are still some work to be done to verify our hypothesized. Therefore, HPAM/ DNS-HM8 suspensions show great potential in polymer flooding to enhance oil recovery from high-temperature and high-salinity oil reservoirs.
Fig. 6 schematically shows the viscometric behavior of HPAM solution, HPAM/DNS-0 suspensions and HPAM/DNS-HM8 suspensions in distilled water. Briefly, when the HPAM particles is dissolved in distilled water, the HPAM molecules tend to form long molecular chains. The long polymer chains undergo intermolecular cross-linking under mild stirring to form a three-dimensional network structure, thereby causing an increase in the viscosity of the HPAM solution (Fig. 6(a)). Upon the addition of DNS-0, the DNS-0 nanoparticles and the long molecular chains of HPAM are connected by hydrogen bonds to form another three-dimensional network structure (Fig. 6(b)), thereby the viscosity of the HPAM/DNS-0 suspensions is higher than HPAM solution. As shown in Fig. 6(c), with the addition of DNS-HM8 also form hydrogen bonds between DNS-HM8 and the long molecular chains of HPAM. But unlike the DNS-0, since the optimum amount of hydrophobic groups on the surface of DNS-HM8 exist, there are hydrophobic association action exist in HPAM/DNS-HM8 suspensions. Due to the hydrophobic association action, the DNS-HM8 particles are tend to move close to each other in aqueous solution, which would make the HPAM chain interwoven with each other more tightly than before. With the formation of hydrogen bonds and hydrophobic association action, in the suspension of HPAM/DNS-HM8 tend to form a more stable threedimensional association network structure, thus making it exhibit better thermal stability and salinity tolerance. Moreover, these properties of the HPAM/DNS-HM8 make it more suitable to be applied to high-temperature and high-salinity reservoir.

sections.heading: 3.4. The stability of suspension and DLS analysis
sections.text:
The stability of HPAM solution, HPAM/DNS-0, HPAM/DNS-HD16 and HPAM/DNS-HM8 suspensions in distilled water were investigated at room temperature. The influence of DNS-0, DNS-HD16 and DNSHM8 on the stability of HPAM solution has been monitored at different times. The result is shown in Fig. 7, it can be seen that the HPAM solution, HPAM/DNS-0, HPAM/DNS-HD16 and HPAM/DNS-HM8 suspensions in distilled water remain homogeneous and show no signs of sedimentation after storage in ambient conditions within 24 h. After 3- day storage, the HPAM solution and HPAM/DNS-HM8 suspensions still remain homogeneous, but there are lamination of HPAM/DNS-0 and HPAM/DNS-HD16 suspensions which tends to become increasingly severe with extending storage time. This indicates that HPAM/DNS-0 and HPAM/DNS-HD16 suspensions exhibit poorer stability than HPAM/DNS-HM8 suspensions. By contrast, the HPAM/DNS-HM8 suspensions in water remains stable and reveal no lamination phenomenon even after 25-day storage. The stability of HPAM/DNS suspensions in water could be closely related to the kinds of hydrophobic group and its modified amount on the surface of DNS. There is no doubt that DNSHM8 with appropriate hydrophobic group play a role in the stability of HPAM/DNS-HM8 suspensions. The improvement of the stability of HPAM/DNS suspensions is due to the common effect of hydrogen bonds and hydrophobic association action, which helps to form a stable threedimensional association network structure in the aqueous solution.
As shown in Fig. 8, the results of DLS measurements showed that the average diameter of HPAM, HPAM/DNS-0, HPAM/DNS-HD16 and HPAM/DNS-HM8 are 2.8 nm, 7.2 nm, 45.2 nm and 29.6 nm, respectively. The accession of nano-SiO2 can increase the average diameter of HPAM solution, which we hypothesized that the hydrogen bonds, between the amide group of HPAM and the silanol radical of nano-
SiO2, make HPAM macromolecular chain intertwine more tighter. Based on our previous mechanism analysis (see the analysis of Fig. 6), the existence of hydrophobic groups on the modified nanoSiO2 are tend to move close to each other with strong hydrophobic association action and forming a three-dimensional association network structure in the aqueous solution, which explains why the average diameter of HPAM/DNS-HD16 and HPAM/DNS-HM8 are bigger than HPAM/DNS-0.

sections.heading: 3.5. Flooding performance of HPAM/DNS suspensions
sections.text:
In order to better simulate the high water cut period in oilfield, we explore the relationship between oil recovery volume and injected pore volume in water flooding processes. The oil recovery volume as a function of injected pore volume of water flooding preliminary experiments results as Fig. 9. It can be seen that the oil recovery volume increases rapidly with injected pore volume of water before 1.5 PV, and then curve became slower gradually. After careful calculation, the water content is more than 95% in produced fluid, when the injected
pore volume of water reached 2.0 PV. And so we thought it is reasonable to choose 2.5 PV of water injection, which meet basically the experiment requirement of water content is more than 98% before chemical flooding.
A series of flooding tests were conducted with 600 mg/L HPAM solution containing DNS-0, DNS-HM8, and DNS-HD16 to observe the effect of the surface-modified nano-SiO2 on the flooding performance of
HPAM. Fig. 10 shows the flooding pressure as a function of the injected volume of HPAM/DNS suspensions under simulated high-temperature oil reservoir environment, and the core parameters, displacement process and the oil displacement test results are shown in Table. 3. It can be seen that the HPAM/DNS-HM8 suspensions displays the best injection performance among various tested HPAM-based suspensions, because the injection pressure gradually increases during the injected
slug of HPAM/DNS-HM8. As post water injection, the injection pressure has a sharply increase and kept a relatively high injection pressure level, which means the slug has played a role in core flooding. In addition, after flooding with HPAM/DNS-HM8 suspensions, the highest oil recovery rate of 10.54% is achieved, which is ascribed to the enhancement in the swept volume and conformance efficiency upon the addition of HPAM/DNS-HM8 suspensions.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this article, a series of different hydrophobic nano-SiO2 were synthesized and the performance of HPAM/DNS suspensions in the viscosity and EOR properties under high-temperature were investigated. The obtained results showed that the apparent viscosity of pure HPAM is 279.2 mP s (1500 mg/L, 80 °C), whereas HPAM/DNS-HM8 and HPAM/DNS-HD16 suspensions can be improved to 613.7 mP s and 528.7 mP s, respectively. Besides, results showed the viscosity of solution increased with addition of nano-SiO2 (0.5–2.0 wt%). After 25-day storage in the normal temperature, there was no lamination phenomenon appeared in HPAM/DNS-HM8 suspensions. on the contrary, the others had different levels of delamination phenomenon. The addition of DNS-0 only formed hydrogen bonds between the hydroxyl groups of the SiO2 and the amide groups in the HPAM molecular chain. The modified nano-SiO2 DNS-HM8, which contain a small amount of hydrophobic groups, those DNS-HM8 tend to move close to each other and form a micro zone of association in aqueous solution. Due to hydrogen bonds and hydrophobic association action, the solutions of HPAM/DNS-HM8 exhibit excellent viscosity and long-term thermal stability. In addition, flooding experiments directly demonstrated that the HPAM/DNS-HM8 samples are more effective at raising viscosity and improving sweep efficiency. 0.6 PV HPAM/DNS-HM8 polymer flooding and subsequent water flooding can further increase the oil
recovery to 10.54%, which is better than 7.08% (HPAM) and 7.70% (HPAM/DNS-0). These obtained positive results, by introducing hydrophobic groups into the surface of nano-SiO2, means HPAM/hydrophobic nano-SiO2 suspension has a promising prospect in polymer flooding for high-temperature (80 °C or more) and high-salinity reservoirs.

metadata.abstractText: In high-temperature and high-salinity oil reservoirs, the poor thermal stability and salinity tolerance of partially hydrolyzed polyacrylamides (HPAM) solution hinder its efficiency in enhanced oil recovery (EOR). Therefore, a series of dispersible nano-SiO2 (denoted as DNS) separately surface-modified by silane coupling agents hexamethyldisilazane (denoted as HMDS) and hexadecyltrimethoxysilane (denoted as HDTS) are prepared by in-situ surface-modification technique. The two types of surface-modified hydrophobic nano-SiO2, i.e., DNS-HM (modified by HMDS) and DNS-HD (modified by HDTS), are separately added into HPAM solution to obtain the HPAM-based suspensions used for EOR. The effects of DNS-HM and DNS-HD on the thermal stability, apparent viscosity, and flooding performance of HPAM are investigated. The results indicate that the HPAM/DNS-HM8 and HPAM/DNS-HD16 (see Table 1) suspensions exhibit better apparent viscosity, storage stability and thermal stability than the HPAM/DNS-0 suspensions. Moreover, HPAM/DNS-HM8 suspension show better flooding performance and has a higher oil recovery factor (about 10.54%) than other HPAM-based suspensions.
